newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish bonds seen rising more on EMU, rate cuts.
newsitem.headline: Spanish bonds seen rising more on EMU, rate cuts.

text.p: Spanish bonds welcomed a widely expected official rate cut on Thursday, and analysts said bonds could climb even higher if the European convergence process continues.
The market has hit record highs since August, as dealers increasingly become convinced the peseta can join a European single currency from the start in 1999.
"Another rate cut is likely before year-end, but what is more important for the bond market is the convergence process," said Luca Jellinek, economist at Paribas Banque in London.
Spain's path towards a unified Europe was being paved by a positive falling trend in the budget deficit and inflation, foreign rate exchange stability and above all, political will, he added.
The 10-year spread over German Bunds has fallen dramatically from 440 basis points in September 1995 to 172 basis points on Tuesday. And nobody expects it to stop there.

"The sheer momentum on the spreads is still there...we'll probably see the Spanish spread moving towards 150 basis points," Phillis Reed, economist at BZW in London, told Reuters Financial Television (RFTV).

But bigger spreads at the short-end of the curve, such as 328 basis points on the two-year segment or 214 on the five year, attest the market is less convinced by European economic and monetary union (EMU) in the short-term, analysts said.
"The market thinks the longer the horizon, the more likely is the union," Jellinek said.
More people were convinced the short-end of the curve could gain further if the convergence process was right on schedule.

On Thursday, shortly after the Bank of Spain cut its key money market rate by 50 basis points, the three-year 7.80-percent bond was trading at 102.13, yielding 6.83 percent, versus Wednesday's close at 101.99.
The 10-year December future contract was at 107.50, 12 basis points above Wednesday's close.
Analysts said another key was what other European nations will do with rates, after the last Bundesbank repo rate cut from 3.30 to 3.00 percent on August 21 triggered a spate of rate reductions.

Benjamin Serrano, economist at Analistas Financieros in Madrid, said the Bank of Spain "had scope to cut one-half point, and they took advantage of it. The Bundesbank's cut in August gave the Bank of Spain room."
But European central banks' room for manoeuvre is narrow due to the inflation criteria imposed by the Maastricht Treaty.
Taming the inflation trend means they have to keep short-term interest rates relatively high while trying to hinder any currency appreciation.
After the Spanish consumer price index came in lower than expected in August at 3.7 percent, the market is now focusing on the September inflation data due on October 11.
"It is very likely the Bank of Spain will wait to see an inflation rate around 3.3 percent and then, they will cut again," said Jellinek.
Others said a cut could come even sooner.
"The Bank of Spain will do its damnedest to keep (the peseta) from gaining much further," said Henrik Lumholdt, chief economist at Bank of America in Madrid.
At 1045 GMT, the peseta was trading at 84.09/11 against the German mark, almost unchanged from Wednesday.
